extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### 

- [X] I have checked that this issue has not already been reported.

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the [latest version](https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/whatsnew/index.html) of pandas.

- [X] I have confirmed this bug exists on the master branch of pandas.


### Reproducible Example

```python
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

index = pd.date_range('2020', periods=4, freq='s')

inc = pd.Series([1,1,1,1], index=index).rolling('3s', center=True).sum()
dec = pd.Series([1,1,1,1], index=index[::-1]).rolling('3s', center=True).sum()

assert np.all(inc.values == dec.values)

>>> inc
2020-01-01 00:00:00    2.0
2020-01-01 00:00:01    3.0
2020-01-01 00:00:02    3.0
2020-01-01 00:00:03    2.0
Freq: S, dtype: float64

>>> dec
2020-01-01 00:00:03    NaN
2020-01-01 00:00:02    3.0
2020-01-01 00:00:01    3.0
2020-01-01 00:00:00    2.0
Freq: -1S, dtype: float64
```


### Issue Description

the first value is a `NaN` when rolling over a decreasing index with `center=True`, but it shouldnt. This happens for ever value of `closed`.  

AFAIK, this comes from the cython implementation of `calculate_valiable_window_bounds`. 

I prepared a MR for this. 



### Expected Behavior

no `NaN` as first value.

    "body": "<s>Needs whatsnew note.</s>\r\n\r\nThis has the benefit of looking a lot like the SparseDataframe._combine_frame implementation.  With luck we can de-duplicate those at some point.\r\n\r\nLikely to be a perf hit for non-td64 dtypes.  One option would be to use dispatch_to_series more selectively, but that gets complicated in a hurry.\r\n\r\nI think long-term the perf solution is going to be to dispatch to EA ops instead of Series ops, as discussed briefly in #22614, but that is a ways away.\r\n\r\n- [x] closes #22537\r\n- [x] tests added / passed\r\n- [x] passes `git diff upstream/master -u -- \"*.py\" | flake8 --diff`\r\n- [x] whatsnew entry\r\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```python
df = pd.DataFrame({'a': [None, 2, 3]}, index=pd.to_datetime(['20170403', '20170404', '20170405']))

df.rolling('3d', min_periods=1)['a'].sum()

df.rolling('3d', min_periods=1)['a'].min()
df.rolling('3d', min_periods=1)['a'].max()
```
#### Problem description
Even if we set `min_periods=1`, the functions `min` and `max` give NaN if there is one NaN value inside the time-aware rolling window.

However, there is no bug when the window width is fixed (not a time period):
```javascript
In [397]: df.rolling(3, min_periods=1)['a'].min()
Out[397]:
2017-04-03    NaN
2017-04-04    2.0
2017-04-05    2.0
Name: a, dtype: float64
```

#### Expected Output
The expected output, analogously to the one given by the function `sum`, should be a non-NaN value if at least there is a non-NaN value inside the rolling window.

```javascript
In [397]: df.rolling('3d', min_periods=1)['a'].min()
Out[397]:
2017-04-03    NaN
2017-04-04    2.0
2017-04-05    2.0
Name: a, dtype: float64

In [397]: df.rolling('3d', min_periods=1)['a'].min()
Out[397]:
2017-04-03    NaN
2017-04-04    2.0
2017-04-05    3.0
Name: a, dtype: float64
```

#### Output of ``pd.show_versions()``

<details>

    "body": "There seem to be some incompatibilities with timezones and timestamps in 0.17.1.\n\nFor example, here I'm trying to clip a timezone-aware column with a timezone-aware timestamp:\n\n```\nIn [224]: import pandas\n\nIn [225]: u = pandas.Timestamp('2015-12-01 09:30:30', tz='US/Eastern')\n\nIn [226]: print u\n2015-12-01 09:30:30-05:00\n\nIn [227]: df = pandas.DataFrame({ 'foo' : [ pandas.Timestamp('2015-12-01 09:30:00', tz='US/Eastern'), pandas.Timestamp('2015-12-01 09:31:00', tz='US/Eastern') ] })\n\nIn [228]: print df\n                        foo\n0 2015-12-01 09:30:00-05:00\n1 2015-12-01 09:31:00-05:00\n\nIn [229]: df['foo'].clip(upper=u)\n\nTypeError: Could not compare [Timestamp('2015-12-01 09:30:30-0500', tz='US/Eastern')] with block values\n```\n\nThis code used to work on 0.16.2.\n",

{
    "body": [
        "There seem to be some incompatibilities with timezones and timestamps in 0.17.1.

For example, here I'm trying to clip a timezone-aware column with a timezone-aware timestamp:

```
In [224]: import pandas

In [225]: u = pandas.Timestamp('2015-12-01 09:30:30', tz='US/Eastern')

In [226]: print u
2015-12-01 09:30:30-05:00

In [227]: df = pandas.DataFrame({ 'foo' : [ pandas.Timestamp('2015-12-01 09:30:00', tz='US/Eastern'), pandas.Timestamp('2015-12-01 09:31:00', tz='US/Eastern') ] })

In [228]: print df
                        foo
0 2015-12-01 09:30:00-05:00
1 2015-12-01 09:31:00-05:00

In [229]: df['foo'].clip(upper=u)

TypeError: Could not compare [Timestamp('2015-12-01 09:30:30-0500', tz='US/Eastern')] with block values
```

This code used to work on 0.16.2.
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "REGR: .clip and datetime w/timezone"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",

{
    "id": 7239081,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/1990",
    "body": "Parking this here so I don't forget about it. I assume that the NaNs here are not comparing equal, so we get \"duplicate\" rows on a merge, which I think is a bug.\n\n```\ndata = [[1950, \"A\", 1.5],\n        [1950, \"B\", 1.5],\n        [1955, \"B\", 1.5],\n        [1960, \"B\", np.nan],\n        [1970, \"B\", 4.],\n        [1950, \"C\", 4.],\n        [1960, \"C\", np.nan],\n        [1965, \"C\", 3.],\n        [1970, \"C\", 4.],\n        ]\nframe = pandas.DataFrame(data, columns=[\"year\", \"panel\", \"data\"])\n\nother_data = [[1960, 'A', np.nan],\n [1970, 'A', np.nan],\n [1955, 'A', np.nan],\n [1965, 'A', np.nan],\n [1965, 'B', np.nan],\n [1955, 'C', np.nan]]\nother = pandas.DataFrame(other_data, columns=['year', 'panel', 'data'])\n\ntogether = frame.merge(other, how=\"outer\")\n```\n\nWorked around this by filling in the NaNs before the merge, but then I have to convert them back to NaNs later.\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Parking this here so I don't forget about it. I assume that the NaNs here are not comparing equal, so we get "duplicate" rows on a merge, which I think is a bug.

```
data = [[1950, "A", 1.5],
        [1950, "B", 1.5],
        [1955, "B", 1.5],
        [1960, "B", np.nan],
        [1970, "B", 4.],
        [1950, "C", 4.],
        [1960, "C", np.nan],
        [1965, "C", 3.],
        [1970, "C", 4.],
        ]
frame = pandas.DataFrame(data, columns=["year", "panel", "data"])

other_data = [[1960, 'A', np.nan],
 [1970, 'A', np.nan],
 [1955, 'A', np.nan],
 [1965, 'A', np.nan],
 [1965, 'B', np.nan],
 [1955, 'C', np.nan]]
other = pandas.DataFrame(other_data, columns=['year', 'panel', 'data'])

together = frame.merge(other, how="outer")
```

Worked around this by filling in the NaNs before the merge, but then I have to convert them back to NaNs later.
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "NaN comparison in merge"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": null
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

body:
{
    "id": 457216976,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/26914",
    "body": "Discussed on the mailing list last week, cc @TomAugspurger @jreback @jorisvandenbossche \r\n\r\nThe central claim: if we allow EAs to take on shapes (N, 1) and (1, N), then we can get some major simplifications in core.internals.\r\n\r\nFor the proof of concept I've made the Datetimelike arrays accept these shapes and updated `DatetimeTZBlock` to see what simplifications are available.  The `_wrap_data` implementation would also work for `Categorical` and `PandasArray`.\r\n\r\nThree categories of simplifications are not in here yet and you'll have to use your imaginations\r\n- some can only be made once all EAs allow these shapes, e.g. not having to pass `ndim` arg to Block constructors\r\n- some would require additional tweaks on the EA subclasses, e.g. making `shift`, `__iter__`, or `take` aware of 2Dness\r\n- some I just haven't got to yet.  core.internals is rough.\r\n\r\nAdded bonus: this fleshes out bugs (see #26864)\r\n\r\n\r\n",
    "user": {
        "id": 8078968,

body:
{
    "id": 832992252,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/18629",
    "body": "Fixes #18609\r\n\r\nThis PR adds a new `min_digits` argument to the dragon4 float printing methods, such as `np.format_float_positional`. This kwd guarantees that at least the given number of digits will be printed, when printing in `unique=True` mode, even if the extra digits are unnecessary to uniquely specify the value. It is the counterpart to the `precision` argument which sets the maximum number of digits to be printed. (When `unique=False` fixed-precision mode, it has no effect, and the `precision` arg fixes the number of digits)\r\n\r\nUsing this new keyword, I then fix a bug in arrayprint ( #18609). The bug in the old code is that, in order to guarantee that all elements of an array print using the same number of digits, we turned off `unique=True` because we needed to use fixed-precision mode to fix the number of digits. However, unique mode rounds differently from fixed-precision mode, so the rounding was wrong. This PR instead now stays in unique mode to print the elements, but uses the `min_digits` and `precision` arguments to fix the number of output digits.\r\n\r\nIt looks like a lof of chages, but a lot of it is just introducing the `min_digits` arg into all the function signatures in dragon4 and in the user api.",
    "user": {
        "id": 9040124,
        "url": "https://api.github.com/users/ahaldane",

{
    "id": 490824608,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/14457",
    "body": "Running the following command on ppc64(be) hangs due to a near-infinite loop:

```python
>>> np.random.hypergeometric([1,2,2], [2], [2])
```

Appears to be related to new code in #13761, perhaps @WarrenWeckesser has an idea. See in particular frame #2 below. It appears a value is negative but the code expects it not to be.

gdb stack trace after breaking during hang:
```
#0  __log (x=-25811282) at ../math/w_log.c:27
#1  0x0ea14754 in loggam (x=-160848451)
    at numpy/random/src/distributions/distributions.c:503
#2  0x0ea1232c in random_hypergeometric_hrua (bitgen_state=0xf76272c8, good=1, 
    bad=2, sample=268080756)
    at numpy/random/src/legacy/legacy-distributions.c:266
#3  0x0ea12798 in random_hypergeometric_original (bitgen_state=0xf76272c8, 
    good=1, bad=2, sample=268080756)
    at numpy/random/src/legacy/legacy-distributions.c:315
#4  0x0ea12844 in legacy_random_hypergeometric (bitgen_state=0xf76272c8, 
    good=1, bad=2, sample=8858015348)
    at numpy/random/src/legacy/legacy-distributions.c:334
#5  0x0e96db10 in __pyx_f_5numpy_6random_6common_discrete_broadcast_iii (
    __pyx_v_func=0xea127e8 <legacy_random_hypergeometric>, 
    __pyx_v_state=0xf76272c8, __pyx_v_size=0x104520e0 <_Py_NoneStruct>, 
    __pyx_v_lock=0xf7647140, __pyx_v_a_arr=0xf754c638, 
    __pyx_v_a_name=0xf7643fa0, 
    __pyx_v_a_constraint=__pyx_e_5numpy_6random_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, 
    __pyx_v_b_arr=0xf754c570, __pyx_v_b_name=0xf7643f80, 
    __pyx_v_b_constraint=__pyx_e_5numpy_6random_6common_CONS_NON_NEGATIVE, 
    __pyx_v_c_arr=0xf754c548, __pyx_v_c_name=0xf7643fe0, 
    __pyx_v_c_constraint=__pyx_e_5numpy_6random_6common_CONS_GTE_1)
    at numpy/random/common.c:13924
---Type <return> to continue, or q <return> to quit---frame 1
#6  0x0e9e7c5c in __pyx_pf_5numpy_6random_6mtrand_11RandomState_96hypergeometric (__pyx_v_self=0xf76272b8, __pyx_v_ngood=0xf7551058, __pyx_v_nbad=0xf754ffa8, 
    __pyx_v_nsample=0xf754fe68, __pyx_v_size=0x104520e0 <_Py_NoneStruct>)
    at numpy/random/mtrand.c:15834
#7  0x0e9e536c in __pyx_pw_5numpy_6random_6mtrand_11RandomState_97hypergeometric (__pyx_v_self=0xf76272b8, __pyx_args=0xf7535b48, __pyx_kwds=0x0)
    at numpy/random/mtrand.c:15312
#8  0x1006ca2c in PyCFunction_Call ()
```

A little bit of gdb exploration so far:
```
(gdb) frame 1
#1  0x0ea14754 in loggam (x=-160848451)
    at numpy/random/src/distributions/distributions.c:503
(gdb) p n
$2 = 160848458
(gdb) p x
$3 = -160848451
(gdb) frame 2
#2  0x0ea1232c in random_hypergeometric_hrua (bitgen_state=0xf76272c8, good=1, 
    bad=2, sample=268080756)
    at numpy/random/src/legacy/legacy-distributions.c:266
266	  d10 = (loggam(d9 + 1) + loggam(mingoodbad - d9 + 1) + loggam(m - d9 + 1) +
(gdb) l
261	  d5 = 1.0 - d4;
262	  d6 = m * d4 + 0.5;
263	  d7 = sqrt((double)(popsize - m) * sample * d4 * d5 / (popsize - 1) + 0.5);
264	  d8 = D1 * d7 + D2;
265	  d9 = (RAND_INT_TYPE)floor((double)(m + 1) * (mingoodbad + 1) / (popsize + 2));
266	  d10 = (loggam(d9 + 1) + loggam(mingoodbad - d9 + 1) + loggam(m - d9 + 1) +
267	         loggam(maxgoodbad - m + d9 + 1));
268	  d11 = MIN(MIN(m, mingoodbad) + 1.0, floor(d6 + 16 * d7));
269	  /* 16 for 16-decimal-digit precision in D1 and D2 */
270	
(gdb) p d9
$4 = -107232301
```

The failing line 266 in the last bit of code is from #13761, but I haven't read it well enough yet to know what it should do.

{
    "id": 7724031,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/841",
    "body": "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/243 on 2006-08-12 by @alberts, assigned to @teoliphant._\n\nAccording to Valgrind 2.4.0, the following code leaks:\n\n```\n#!python\nimport numpy\nx = numpy.zeros((1,))\ny = [0]\nfrom numpy.core import around\ndecimal = 6\naround(abs(x-y),decimal) <= 10.0**(-decimal)\n```\n\nValgrind error:\n\n```\n==15583== 56 (40 direct, 16 indirect) bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 8 of 28\n==15583==    at 0x40051F9: malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:149)\n==15583==    by 0x4434AF2: array_alloc (arrayobject.c:6445)\n==15583==    by 0x443C59A: PyArray_NewFromDescr (arrayobject.c:5063)\n==15583==    by 0x443E4B3: PyArray_Empty (multiarraymodule.c:5036)\n==15583==    by 0x4460CD8: PyArray_Round (multiarraymodule.c:293)\n==15583==    by 0x4460E2C: array_round (arraymethods.c:1652)\n==15583==    by 0x5F15CFC: PyCFunction_Call (in /usr/lib/libpython2.4.so.1.0)\n...\n```\n\nTested with !NumPy 1.0b2.dev3000.\n",

        "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/243 on 2006-08-12 by @alberts, assigned to @teoliphant._

According to Valgrind 2.4.0, the following code leaks:

```
#!python
import numpy
x = numpy.zeros((1,))
y = [0]
from numpy.core import around
decimal = 6
around(abs(x-y),decimal) <= 10.0**(-decimal)
```

Valgrind error:

```
==15583== 56 (40 direct, 16 indirect) bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 8 of 28
==15583==    at 0x40051F9: malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:149)
==15583==    by 0x4434AF2: array_alloc (arrayobject.c:6445)
==15583==    by 0x443C59A: PyArray_NewFromDescr (arrayobject.c:5063)
==15583==    by 0x443E4B3: PyArray_Empty (multiarraymodule.c:5036)
==15583==    by 0x4460CD8: PyArray_Round (multiarraymodule.c:293)
==15583==    by 0x4460E2C: array_round (arraymethods.c:1652)
==15583==    by 0x5F15CFC: PyCFunction_Call (in /usr/lib/libpython2.4.so.1.0)
...
```

Tested with !NumPy 1.0b2.dev3000.
"

    "body": "~~This is a WIP, in particular, the examples need fixing, tests need to be added, and a decision should be made whether to access these functions through a dtype argument in the current `random_integers` function. If the latter is chosen rk_functions for uint8, uint16, and maybe bool need to be added for efficiency, on the other hand, less new documentation needs to be written ;)~~\n\nThe following dtypes are now available from the new `dtype` argument added to randint.\n\n```\n* np.bool,\n* np.int8, np.uint8,\n* np.int16, np.uint16,\n* np.int32, np.uint32,\n* np.int64, np.uint64,\n* np.int_ (long), np.intp\n```\n\nTests for all the new functionality are needed, but things seem to work. It should also be almost trivial to template the code added to mtrant.pyx, the 9 added functions only differ in using different types.\n\nWhen merged #6812 will be closed and the integer part of #6790 will be done..\n\n~~Alternate PR's addressing this are #6824 and #6869, but I like this one as far as it goes.~~\n",

{
    "id": 7727329,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/1507",
    "body": "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/909 on 2008-09-10 by trac user ChrisBarker, assigned to unknown._\n\n == Proposed Enhancements and bug fixes for `fromfile()` and `fromstring()` text handling: == \n\n === Motivation: === \n\nThe goal of the `fromfile()` text file handling capability is to enable users to write code that can read a lot of numbers from a text file into an array. Python provides a lot of nifty text processing capabilities, and there are a number of higher level facilities for reading blocks of data (including `numpy.loadtxt`). These are very capable, but there really is a significant performance hit, at least when loading 10s of thousands of numbers into a file. \n\nWe don't want to write all of `loadtxt(`) and friends in C. Rather, the goal is to allow the simple cases to be done very efficiently, and hopefully fancier text reading packages can build on it to add more features.\n\nUnfortunately, the current (numpy version 1.2) version has a few bugs and limitations that keep of from being nearly as useful as it could be.\n\n === Possible features: === \n-  Create `fromtextfile()` and `fromtextstring` functions, distinct from `fromfile()` and `fromstring()`. It really is a different functionality. `fromfile(`) could still call `fromtextfile()` for backward compatibility.\n-  Allow more than one separator? for example, a comma or whitespace? In the general case, the user could perhaps specify any number of separators, though I doubt that would be useful in practice. At the very least, however, `fromtextfile()` should support reading files that look like:\n  \n  43.5, 345.6, 123.456, 234.33\n  34.5, 22.57, 2345,  2345, 252\n  ...\n\nThat is, comma separated, but being able to read multiple lines in one shot.\n\nThe easiest way to support that would probably be to always allow whitespace as a separator, and add the one passed in. I can't think of a reason not to do this, but maybe I'm not very imaginative.\n- Allow the user to specify a shape for the output array. There may be little point, as all this does is save a calls to reshape(), but it may be another way to support the above. i.e. you could read that data with:\n  \n  `a = np.fromtextfile(infile, dtype=np.float, sep=',', shape=(-1, 4))`\n  \n  Then it would know to skip the newlines every 4 elements.\n-  Allow the user to specify a comment string. The reader would then skip everything in the file between the comment string and a newline. Maybe Universal newline -- any of \\r, \\n or \\r\\n. Or simply expect that the user has opened the file with mode 'U' if they want that. This could also be extended to support C-style comments with an opening and closing character sequence, but that's a lot less common.\n-  Allow the user to specify a Locale. It may be best to be able to specify a locale, rather than relying on the system on (whether '.' or ',' is the decimal separator, for instance. (ticket #1482)\n- parsing of \"Inf\" and the like that doesn't depend on system (ticket #1108). This would be nice, but maybe too difficult -- would we need to write our own `scanf`?\n  \n  === Bugs to be fixed: === \n- `fromfile()` and `fromstring` handling malformed data poorly: ticket #1481\n- Any others?\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/909 on 2008-09-10 by trac user ChrisBarker, assigned to unknown._

 == Proposed Enhancements and bug fixes for `fromfile()` and `fromstring()` text handling: == 

 === Motivation: === 

The goal of the `fromfile()` text file handling capability is to enable users to write code that can read a lot of numbers from a text file into an array. Python provides a lot of nifty text processing capabilities, and there are a number of higher level facilities for reading blocks of data (including `numpy.loadtxt`). These are very capable, but there really is a significant performance hit, at least when loading 10s of thousands of numbers into a file. 

We don't want to write all of `loadtxt(`) and friends in C. Rather, the goal is to allow the simple cases to be done very efficiently, and hopefully fancier text reading packages can build on it to add more features.

Unfortunately, the current (numpy version 1.2) version has a few bugs and limitations that keep of from being nearly as useful as it could be.

 === Possible features: === 
-  Create `fromtextfile()` and `fromtextstring` functions, distinct from `fromfile()` and `fromstring()`. It really is a different functionality. `fromfile(`) could still call `fromtextfile()` for backward compatibility.
-  Allow more than one separator? for example, a comma or whitespace? In the general case, the user could perhaps specify any number of separators, though I doubt that would be useful in practice. At the very least, however, `fromtextfile()` should support reading files that look like:
  
  43.5, 345.6, 123.456, 234.33
  34.5, 22.57, 2345,  2345, 252
  ...

That is, comma separated, but being able to read multiple lines in one shot.

The easiest way to support that would probably be to always allow whitespace as a separator, and add the one passed in. I can't think of a reason not to do this, but maybe I'm not very imaginative.
- Allow the user to specify a shape for the output array. There may be little point, as all this does is save a calls to reshape(), but it may be another way to support the above. i.e. you could read that data with:
  
  `a = np.fromtextfile(infile, dtype=np.float, sep=',', shape=(-1, 4))`
  
  Then it would know to skip the newlines every 4 elements.
-  Allow the user to specify a comment string. The reader would then skip everything in the file between the comment string and a newline. Maybe Universal newline -- any of \r, \n or \r\n. Or simply expect that the user has opened the file with mode 'U' if they want that. This could also be extended to support C-style comments with an opening and closing character sequence, but that's a lot less common.
-  Allow the user to specify a Locale. It may be best to be able to specify a locale, rather than relying on the system on (whether '.' or ',' is the decimal separator, for instance. (ticket #1482)
- parsing of "Inf" and the like that doesn't depend on system (ticket #1108). This would be nice, but maybe too difficult -- would we need to write our own `scanf`?
  
  === Bugs to be fixed: === 
- `fromfile()` and `fromstring` handling malformed data poorly: ticket #1481
- Any others?
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "fromstring() / fromfile() Enhancements (Trac #909)"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "01 - Enhancement",
            "description": null
        },
        {
            "name": "component: numpy.core",
            "description": null
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\n\nWhen attempting to set gid to `500` via the `user.present` function, I get this:\n\n> These values could not be changed: {'gid': 500}` \n\nFull output:\n\n```\nbs01gen04:\n----------\n          ID: iruser\n    Function: user.present\n      Result: False\n     Comment: These values could not be changed: {'gid': 500}\n     Started: 09:48:00.789856\n    Duration: 133.02 ms\n     Changes:\n              ----------\n              uid:\n                  500\n```\n### Setup\n\nThe user was created via [kickstart file](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/Installation_Guide/sect-kickstart-syntax.html), CentOS 7:\n\n```\nuser --groups=wheel --name=iruser --password=xxx --iscrypted --gecos=\"Myco user\"\n```\n\n`users.sls` file contents:\n\n```\niruser:\n  user.present:\n    - fullname: Myco user\n    - home: /home/iruser\n    - uid: 500\n    - gid: 500\n    - groups:\n      - wheel\n```\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\n\n```\nsalt 'bs01gen04' state.apply users.sls\n```\n### Versions Report\n\n```\nSalt Version:\n           Salt: 2015.8.7\n\nDependency Versions:\n         Jinja2: 2.7.2\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\n           Mako: Not Installed\n         PyYAML: 3.11\n          PyZMQ: 14.7.0\n         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2015, 02:00:19)\n           RAET: Not Installed\n        Tornado: 4.2.1\n            ZMQ: 4.0.5\n           cffi: Not Installed\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\n       dateutil: Not Installed\n          gitdb: 0.6.4\n      gitpython: 1.0.2\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n        libgit2: Not Installed\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n msgpack-python: 0.4.6\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\n      pycparser: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n         pygit2: Not Installed\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\n          smmap: 0.9.0\n        timelib: Not Installed\n\nSystem Versions:\n           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core\n        machine: x86_64\n        release: 3.10.0-123.el7.x86_64\n         system: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core\n```\n",

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

When attempting to set gid to `500` via the `user.present` function, I get this:

> These values could not be changed: {'gid': 500}` 

Full output:

```
bs01gen04:
----------
          ID: iruser
    Function: user.present
      Result: False
     Comment: These values could not be changed: {'gid': 500}
     Started: 09:48:00.789856
    Duration: 133.02 ms
     Changes:
              ----------
              uid:
                  500
```
### Setup

The user was created via [kickstart file](https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-US/Red_Hat_Enterprise_Linux/7/html/Installation_Guide/sect-kickstart-syntax.html), CentOS 7:

```
user --groups=wheel --name=iruser --password=xxx --iscrypted --gecos="Myco user"
```

`users.sls` file contents:

```
iruser:
  user.present:
    - fullname: Myco user
    - home: /home/iruser
    - uid: 500
    - gid: 500
    - groups:
      - wheel
```
### Steps to Reproduce Issue

```
salt 'bs01gen04' state.apply users.sls
```
### Versions Report

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2015.8.7

Dependency Versions:
         Jinja2: 2.7.2

System Versions:
           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.10.0-123.el7.x86_64
         system: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core
```

{
    "id": 72130776,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/23213",
    "body": "I saw @nmadhok is working on a VMware driver for Salt-cloud (to replace the vsphere one?). \nPretty cool! We're using the stable version of Salt-{master|minion} but it appears I can just simply add in the `vmware.py` from develop to the correct folder and it seems to work fine. :)\n\nQuerying information works great, and after creating a Template VM and a `cloud.profile` for my VM I issued the command to spin it up:\n\n```\nsalt-cloud -p vmware-ubuntu14.04 testvm.example.com\n```\n\nvSphere shows an active cloning task which around >90% completionfailed with an error about it not having a hostname:\n\n```\nA specified parameter was not correct. spec.identity.hostName\n```\n\nThe VM was created though and had the correct name in the VM-tree.\nSalt-cloud displayed an error and did not proceed with the provisioning:\n\n```\n[ERROR   ] Error creating testvm.example.com: (vmodl.fault.InvalidArgument) {\n   dynamicType = <unset>,\n   dynamicProperty = (vmodl.DynamicProperty) [],\n   msg = 'A specified parameter was not correct. \\nspec.identity.hostName',\n   faultCause = <unset>,\n   faultMessage = (vmodl.LocalizableMessage) [],\n   invalidProperty = u'spec.identity.hostName'\n}\nError: There was a profile error: Failed to deploy VM\n```\n\nVersion details:\n\n```\n                  Salt: 2014.7.5\n                Python: 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:56)\n                Jinja2: 2.7.2\n              M2Crypto: 0.21.1\n        msgpack-python: 0.3.0\n          msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n              pycrypto: 2.6.1\n               libnacl: Not Installed\n                PyYAML: 3.10\n                 ioflo: Not Installed\n                 PyZMQ: 14.0.1\n                  RAET: Not Installed\n                   ZMQ: 4.0.4\n                  Mako: 0.9.1\n       Apache Libcloud: 0.14.1\n Debian source package: 2014.7.5+ds-1ubuntu1\n```\n",

{
    "body": [
        "I saw @nmadhok is working on a VMware driver for Salt-cloud (to replace the vsphere one?). 
Pretty cool! We're using the stable version of Salt-{master|minion} but it appears I can just simply add in the `vmware.py` from develop to the correct folder and it seems to work fine. :)

Querying information works great, and after creating a Template VM and a `cloud.profile` for my VM I issued the command to spin it up:

```
salt-cloud -p vmware-ubuntu14.04 testvm.example.com
```

vSphere shows an active cloning task which around >90% completionfailed with an error about it not having a hostname:

```
A specified parameter was not correct. spec.identity.hostName
```

The VM was created though and had the correct name in the VM-tree.
Salt-cloud displayed an error and did not proceed with the provisioning:

```
[ERROR   ] Error creating testvm.example.com: (vmodl.fault.InvalidArgument) {
   dynamicType = <unset>,
   dynamicProperty = (vmodl.DynamicProperty) [],
   msg = 'A specified parameter was not correct. \nspec.identity.hostName',
   faultCause = <unset>,
   faultMessage = (vmodl.LocalizableMessage) [],
   invalidProperty = u'spec.identity.hostName'
}
Error: There was a profile error: Failed to deploy VM
```

Version details:

```
                  Salt: 2014.7.5
                Python: 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:56)
                Jinja2: 2.7.2
              M2Crypto: 0.21.1
        msgpack-python: 0.3.0
          msgpack-pure: Not Installed
              pycrypto: 2.6.1
               libnacl: Not Installed
                PyYAML: 3.10
                 ioflo: Not Installed
                 PyZMQ: 14.0.1
                  RAET: Not Installed
                   ZMQ: 4.0.4
                  Mako: 0.9.1
       Apache Libcloud: 0.14.1
 Debian source package: 2014.7.5+ds-1ubuntu1
```

body:
{
    "id": 565742597,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/32023",
    "body": "#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible\r\n\r\n```python\r\n>>> import pandas as pd\r\n>>> year_2017 = pd.Interval(pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01 00:00:00'),\r\n                                              pd.Timestamp('2018-01-01 00:00:00'))\r\n>>> year_2017\r\nInterval('2017-01-01', '2018-01-01', closed='right')\r\n\r\n>>> year_2017 + pd.Timedelta(days=7)\r\nTraceback (most recent call last):\r\n  File \"<stdin>\", line 1, in <module>\r\nTypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'pandas._libs.interval.Interval' and 'Timedelta'\r\n```\r\n#### Problem description\r\n\r\nFrom the [pd.Interval documentation](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/1.0.1/reference/api/pandas.Interval.html):\r\n\r\n> You can operate with + and * over an Interval and the operation is applied to each of its bounds, so the result depends on the type of the bound elements\r\n\r\nHowever , we can apply the + operation manually on each bounds:\r\n```python\r\n>>> (year_2017.left + pd.Timedelta(days=7), year_2017.right + pd.Timedelta(days=7) )\r\n(Timestamp('2017-01-08 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2018-01-08 00:00:00'))\r\n```\r\n\r\n#### Expected Output\r\n\r\nThe extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "#### Code Sample, a copy-pastable example if possible

```python
>>> import pandas as pd
>>> year_2017 = pd.Interval(pd.Timestamp('2017-01-01 00:00:00'),
                                              pd.Timestamp('2018-01-01 00:00:00'))
>>> year_2017
Interval('2017-01-01', '2018-01-01', closed='right')

>>> year_2017 + pd.Timedelta(days=7)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for +: 'pandas._libs.interval.Interval' and 'Timedelta'
```
#### Problem description

From the [pd.Interval documentation](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/version/1.0.1/reference/api/pandas.Interval.html):

> You can operate with + and * over an Interval and the operation is applied to each of its bounds, so the result depends on the type of the bound elements

However , we can apply the + operation manually on each bounds:
```python
>>> (year_2017.left + pd.Timedelta(days=7), year_2017.right + pd.Timedelta(days=7) )
(Timestamp('2017-01-08 00:00:00'), Timestamp('2018-01-08 00:00:00'))
```

#### Expected Output

The same as the manual operation on each bounds:

```python
>>> pd.Interval(year_2017.left + pd.Timedelta(days=7), 
                         year_2017.right + pd.Timedelta(days=7) )
Interval('2017-01-08', '2018-01-08', closed='right')
```
#### Output of ``pd.show_versions()``

pandas 1.0.1
<details>

>>> pd.show_versions()

INSTALLED VERSIONS
------------------
commit           : None

python-bits      : 64

body:
{
    "id": 340076803,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/21853",
    "body": "User reported that `df.rolling(to_offset('3D'), closed='left').max()`\r\nsegfaults when df has a datetime index. The bug was in PR #19549. In\r\nthat PR, in https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blame/master/pandas/_libs/window.pyx#L1268\r\n`i` is initialized to `endi[0]`, which is 0 when `closed=left`.\r\nSo in the next line when it tries to set `output[i-1]` it goes out of bounds.\r\nIn addition, there are 2 more bugs in the `roll_min_max` code.\r\nThe second bug is that for variable size windows, the `nobs` is never updated\r\nwhen elements leave the window. The third bug is at the end of the fixed\r\nwindow where all output elements up to `minp` are initialized to 0 if\r\nthe input is not float.\r\n\r\nThis PR fixes all three of the aforementioned bugs, at the cost of casting the\r\noutput array to floating point even if the input is integer. This is less\r\nthan ideal if the output has no NaNs, but is still consistent with roll_sum\r\nbehavior.\r\n\r\n- [x] closes #21704\r\n- [x] tests added / passed\r\n- [x] passes `git diff upstream/master -u -- \"*.py\" | flake8 --diff`\r\n- [x] whatsnew entry\r\n",

body: { "id": 716517326, "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/17489", "body": "Hello,\r\n\r\nWhile analyzing numpy on SonarCloud I saw what looks like an error in [`numpy/distutils/system_info.py`](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/385575faba79b5c857112199206119bf9ac2277f/numpy/distutils/system_info.py#L293):\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nYou can see the issue in SonarCloud [here](https://sonarcloud.io/project/issues?id=nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource_numpy&issues=AXUCzxJG_fo4ewk0XE72&open=AXUCzxJG_fo4ewk0XE72).\r\n\r\nThe condition of this `if` statement will always be False because it compares a `tuple` and a string with the operator `==`. The [documentation of `platform.architecture()`](https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/platform.html#platform.architecture) explicitly says:\r\n> Returns a tuple (bits, linkage) which contain information about the bit architecture and the linkage format used for the executable. Both values are returned as strings.\r\n\r\nI guess the developer intended to write instead:\r\n```\r\nif platform.architecture()[0] == '32bit':\r\n```\r\n\r\nIn case you have any question, suggestion or if you see a False Positive on SonarCloud you can reach out on [SonarSource community forum](https://community.sonarsource.com/).\r\n\r\nA few notes in case you want to use SonarCloud:\r\n* I am currently testing the python analyzer so [the numpy project I created on SonarCloud](https://sonarcloud.io/dashboard?id=nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource_numpy) will only show python issues, but SonarCloud can also analyze C/C++ code and other languages.\r\n* SonarCloud can easily import pylint and flake8 issues in case you want to use a rule SonarCloud does not already provide. Note however that pylint/flake8 rules and SonarCloud rules are implemented differently. You might see new issues with SonarCloud, or less issues in some cases (we try to avoid False Positives as much as possible).\r\n* SonarCloud is free for open-source projects.", "user": { "id": 40498978, "url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource", "type": "User", "login": "nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource", "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjQwNDk4OTc4", "html_url": "https://github.com/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource", "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/gists{/gist_id}", "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/repos", "avatar_url": "https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/40498978?v=4", "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/events{/privacy}", "site_admin": false, "gravatar_id": "", "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/starred{/owner}{/repo}", "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/followers", "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/following{/other_user}", "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/orgs", "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/subscriptions", "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/nicolas-harraudeau-sonarsource/received_events" }, "state": "closed", "title": "Condition comparing incompatible types in \"numpy.distutils.system_info.libpaths\"", "labels": [ { "id": 6359214, "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/00%20-%20Bug", "name": "00 - Bug", "color": "fef2c0", "default": false, "node_id": "MDU6TGFiZWw2MzU5MjE0", "description": null }, { "id": 16917063, "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.distutils", "name": "component: numpy.distutils", "color": "009800", "default": false, "node_id": "MDU6TGFiZWwxNjkxNzA2Mw==", "description": null } ], "locked": false, "number": 17489, "node_id": "MDU6SXNzdWU3MTY1MTczMjY=", "assignee": null, "comments": 7, "html_url": "https://github.com/numpy/numpy/issues/17489", "assignees": [], "closed_at": "2020-11-10T18:10:58Z", "milestone": null, "reactions": { "+1": 0, "-1": 0, "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/17489/reactions", "eyes": 0, "heart": 0, "laugh": 0, "hooray": 0, "rocket": 0, "confused": 0, "total_count": 0 }, "created_at": "2020-10-07T13:11:00Z", "events_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/17489/events", "labels_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/17489/labels{/name}", "updated_at": "2020-11-10T18:10:58Z", "comments_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/17489/comments", "timeline_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/17489/timeline", "repository_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy", "active_lock_reason": null, "author_association": "NONE", "performed_via_github_app": null }

body:
{
    "id": 554452947,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/15411",
    "body": "In many cases this likely half works in the interplay of ufuncs (which simply check for `PyErr_Occured()` and loops/cast methods, which also check and skip further evaluation if an error has already occured.\r\n\r\nA simple example for this is:\r\n```python\r\narr = np.array([1, 2, 3, None, 4], dtype=object)\r\ni = np.nditer(arr, flags=[\"refs_ok\", \"grow_inner\", \"buffered\", \"delay_bufalloc\"],\r\n                    op_dtypes=[\"int64\"], casting=\"unsafe\")\r\n# Does the actual casting/buffer filling\r\ni.reset()\r\n```\r\n(identical result without `\"delay_bufalloc\"` during nditer setup)\r\n\r\nRight now the transfer/cast functions are not capable of returning an error (same as ufunc loops). This is something that must be fixed, but even when it is fixed, `nditer` will need to be updated to stop looping when such an error occured. Additionally `nditer` users/cleanup would need to check for that.\r\n\r\nIn particular, `NpyIter_Dealloc` is already capable of returning an error value, but we do not actually check for it. Or alternatively, we may use a pattern of `do {...} while (err = iternext());` I suppose (although `NpyIter_Dealloc` is necessary in any case, the question is whether it will happen first thing after the loop always, at the end of the iteration a Python Error could be set, unless we store that error until `Dealloc` or some error probing function is called...).",

{
    "id": 137020138,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/7360",
    "body": "Running\n\n```\nfrom pathlib import Path\nimport numpy as np\nnp.arange(300000) / Path(\"foo\")\n```\n\nraises\n\n```\nTypeError: argument should be a path or str object, not <class 'int'>\n\nDuring handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:\n\nSystemError: <built-in method __new__ of type object at 0x7fb4df227fc0> returned a result with an error set\n\n<elided: many repeats of the same>\n\nDuring handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:\n\nSystemError: <built-in method __new__ of type object at 0x7fb4df227fc0> returned a result with an error set\n\nDuring handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:\n\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  File \"/tmp/foo.py\", line 3, in <module>\n    np.arange(300000) / Path(\"foo\")\n  File \"/usr/lib/python3.5/pathlib.py\", line 879, in __rtruediv__\n    return self._from_parts([key] + self._parts)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python3.5/pathlib.py\", line 637, in _from_parts\n    self = object.__new__(cls)\nSystemError: <built-in method __new__ of type object at 0x7fb4df227fc0> returned a result with an error set\n```\n\nNote that this does NOT appear for small arrays; I haven't determined the threshold.\nCrossposted as http://bugs.python.org/issue26453.\nPython 3.5.1, numpy 1.10.4.\n",

{
    "body": [
        "Running

```
from pathlib import Path
import numpy as np
np.arange(300000) / Path("foo")
```

raises

```
TypeError: argument should be a path or str object, not <class 'int'>

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

SystemError: <built-in method __new__ of type object at 0x7fb4df227fc0> returned a result with an error set

<elided: many repeats of the same>

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

SystemError: <built-in method __new__ of type object at 0x7fb4df227fc0> returned a result with an error set

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/tmp/foo.py", line 3, in <module>
    np.arange(300000) / Path("foo")
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/pathlib.py", line 879, in __rtruediv__
    return self._from_parts([key] + self._parts)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/pathlib.py", line 637, in _from_parts
    self = object.__new__(cls)
SystemError: <built-in method __new__ of type object at 0x7fb4df227fc0> returned a result with an error set
```

Note that this does NOT appear for small arrays; I haven't determined the threshold.
Crossposted as http://bugs.python.org/issue26453.
Python 3.5.1, numpy 1.10.4.
"

{
    "id": 7731522,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/2482",
    "body": "_Original ticket http://projects.scipy.org/numpy/ticket/1889 on 2011-06-30 by trac user maldun, assigned to @cournape._

I'm working on Ubuntu 10.10/11.04, and Opensuse 11.4. I installed Gentoo prefix on both systems and compiled the blas lapack and atlas versions from. 

No I installed numpy linked with the libraries from prefix
On Ubuntu it worked fine. On openSuse I got the following error message when I try to import numpy

```
parmenides@math146 ~/gentoo $ python
Python 2.7.1 (r271:86832, Jun 30 2011, 08:50:27) 
[GCC 4.4.5] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import numpy
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/parmenides/gentoo/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/__init__.py", line 136, in <module>
    import add_newdocs
  File "/home/parmenides/gentoo/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/add_newdocs.py", line 9, in <module>
    from numpy.lib import add_newdoc
  File "/home/parmenides/gentoo/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/lib/__init__.py", line 13, in <module>
    from polynomial import *
  File "/home/parmenides/gentoo/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/lib/polynomial.py", line 17, in <module>
    from numpy.linalg import eigvals, lstsq
  File "/home/parmenides/gentoo/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/linalg/__init__.py", line 48, in <module>
    from linalg import *
  File "/home/parmenides/gentoo/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/linalg/linalg.py", line 23, in <module>
    from numpy.linalg import lapack_lite
ImportError: liblapack.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
>>> quit()
```

but blas, lapack and atlas should have been built properly.

Then after some other failed experiments I tried my build of lapack_lite.so from ubuntu in the opensuse version and got this:

```
....
    from numpy.linalg import lapack_lite
ImportError: liblapack.so.3gf: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

when I opended with emacs the lapack_lite.so with my emacs I found this entry within the assembler code:

```
liblapack.so.3gf...libblas.so.3gf
```

The gag behind this is that this doesn't appear in my directory where I installed blas, lapack and atlas but in my /usr/lib directory. But my site cfg holds the following:

```
[atlas]
include_dirs = /home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/include  
library_dirs = /home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib/blas/threaded-atlas:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib/blas/reference:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib/lapack/atlas:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib
atlas_libs = cblas, atlas, blas  
lapack_libs = lapack, blas, cblas, atlas  
[blas_opt]
include_dirs = /home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/include  
library_dirs = /home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib/blas/threaded-atlas:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib/blas/reference:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib
libraries = cblas, atlas, blas  
[lapack_opt]
library_dirs = /home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib/lapack/atlas:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib/blas/reference:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib/blas/threaded-atlas:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib
libraries = lapack, blas, cblas, atlas  
```

and those files are not located there!

My PATH, LIBRARY_PATH, and LD_LIBRARY_PATH also don't point there:

```
maldun@math112:~/Gentoo$ echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH
/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib:/home/maldun/Gentoo/lib/
maldun@math112:~/Gentoo$ echo $LIBRARY_PATH
/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/lib:/home/maldun/Gentoo/lib/
maldun@math112:~/Gentoo$ echo $PATH                        
/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/bin:/home/maldun/Gentoo/bin:/home/maldun/Gentoo/opt/bin:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/sbin:/home/maldun/Gentoo/sbin:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/binutils-bin/2.21.51.0.7:/home/maldun/Gentoo/usr/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/gcc-bin/4.4.5
```

This shouldn't be happening if I want to build exclusively with one version of BLAS/LAPACK/ATLAS, but I don't know how to fix this issue!

Please help me!

greez,
maldun

body:
{
    "id": 105216447,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/issues/6288",
    "body": "Following on from PR #6029, the methods provided ignore range or weights so this PR aims to address this. \n\nThe estimators are still defined as separate functions if there is ever a future need to expose these estimators to users. Each estimator now takes x and weights as arguments. These subfunctions expectation of `weights` is that it is count-like. If it's a probability, the subfunctions won't choose the datasize properly.\n\n`_hist_optim_numbins_estimator` handles the range keyword by masking the appropriate parts of `a` and `weights`. It also checks whether weights is of an appropriate dtype (int or float). If weights is probability-like (i.e. `weights.sum()<a.size`), I scale weights such that `weights.sum()=a.size`. This means that I effectively choose  `n=max(a.size, weights.sum())` for my datasize, allowing for decent behaviour whether weights is count-like or probability like, while keeping things simple.\n\nFreedman Diaconis requires a weighted IQR to be calculated, and since `np.percentile` or `np.partition` does not provide weighted options, this method is only used for unweighted data. Trying to use the 'FD' estimator with weights results in a `TypeError`. 'auto' now chooses between 'sturges' and 'scott' for weighted data, while retaining original behaviour for unweighted data. \n\nI've put some basic tests together and minor changes to the documentation and would love to hear others thoughts and feedback on the design choices/implementation/style etc.\n",

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nEven if I specify a custom port (in /etc/salt/master) to the pillar/postgres configuration, salt-mater is trying to connect to the default port\r\n\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\n\r\nsalt-master 2017.7.1+ds-1\r\n\r\nin /etc/salt/master:\r\n...\r\npostgres:\r\n  user: 'USER'\r\n  pass: 'PASS'\r\n  db: 'DB'\r\n  host: 'HOST'\r\n  port: 'PORT'\r\n\r\next_pillar:\r\n  - postgres:\r\n    - query: \"MYQUERY\"\r\n      depth: 3\r\n      as_list: True\r\n...\r\n\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\n\r\ncalling pillar.ls, got this in syslog :\r\n[CRITICAL] Pillar render error: Failed to load ext_pillar postgres: could not connect to server: Connection refused\r\nIs the server running on host \"HOST\" (IP) and accepting TCP/IP connections on port **5432**?\r\n\r\ntcpdump confirms that queries are arriving on (default) port **5432** instead of the given one\r\n\r\n\r\n### How to solve\r\n\r\nedit file /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/pillar/postgres.py\r\n\r\nin function _get_cursor, replace :\r\n\r\n        conn = psycopg2.connect(host=_options['host'],\r\n                                user=_options['user'],\r\n                                password=_options['pass'],\r\n                                dbname=_options['db'])\r\n\r\nwith\r\n\r\n        conn = psycopg2.connect(host=_options['host'],\r\n                                user=_options['user'],\r\n                                password=_options['pass'],\r\n                                dbname=_options['db'],\r\n                                port=_options['port'])\r\n\r\nit works",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

Even if I specify a custom port (in /etc/salt/master) to the pillar/postgres configuration, salt-mater is trying to connect to the default port


### Setup

salt-master 2017.7.1+ds-1

in /etc/salt/master:
...
postgres:
  user: 'USER'
  pass: 'PASS'
  db: 'DB'
  host: 'HOST'
  port: 'PORT'

ext_pillar:
  - postgres:
    - query: "MYQUERY"
      depth: 3
      as_list: True
...


### Steps to Reproduce Issue

calling pillar.ls, got this in syslog :
[CRITICAL] Pillar render error: Failed to load ext_pillar postgres: could not connect to server: Connection refused
Is the server running on host "HOST" (IP) and accepting TCP/IP connections on port **5432**?

tcpdump confirms that queries are arriving on (default) port **5432** instead of the given one


### How to solve

edit file /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/pillar/postgres.py

in function _get_cursor, replace :

        conn = psycopg2.connect(host=_options['host'],
                                user=_options['user'],
                                password=_options['pass'],
                                dbname=_options['db'])

with

        conn = psycopg2.connect(host=_options['host'],
                                user=_options['user'],
                                password=_options['pass'],
                                dbname=_options['db'],
                                port=_options['port'])

it works"
    ],
    "title": [
        "unable to retrieve pillar data in postgres db"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",
            "description": "broken, incorrect, or confusing behavior"
        },
        {
            "name": "Core",
            "description": "relates to code central or existential to Salt"
        },
        {
            "name": "P2",
            "description": "Priority 2"
        },
        {
            "name": "Pillar",
            "description": null
        },
        {
            "name": "severity-medium",
            "description": "3rd level, incorrect or bad functionality, confusing and lacks a work around"
        }
    ],
    "description": []
}

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\r\n\r\nI'm setting up salt-cloud to spin up minions with EC2/Windows, using the sample userdata in:\r\n\r\nhttps://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/topics/cloud/windows.html\r\n\r\n, but the script seemingly does not execute. If I go into the box, I see that the ps1 file is present, but without any newlines. Indeed, adding `;` to each line fixes the issue\r\n\r\n### Setup\r\n\r\nUserdata:\r\n\r\n```\r\n<powershell>\r\nNew-NetFirewallRule -Name \"SMB445\" -DisplayName \"SMB445\" -Protocol TCP -LocalPort 445;\r\nNew-NetFirewallRule -Name \"WINRM5986\" -DisplayName \"WINRM5986\" -Protocol TCP -LocalPort 5986;\r\n\r\nwinrm quickconfig -q;\r\nwinrm set winrm/config/winrs '@{MaxMemoryPerShellMB=\"300\"}';\r\nwinrm set winrm/config '@{MaxTimeoutms=\"1800000\"}';\r\nwinrm set winrm/config/service/auth '@{Basic=\"true\"}';\r\n\r\n$SourceStoreScope = 'LocalMachine';\r\n$SourceStorename = 'Remote Desktop';\r\n\r\n$SourceStore = New-Object  -TypeName System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store  -ArgumentList $SourceStorename, $SourceStoreScope;\r\n$SourceStore.Open([System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.OpenFlags]::ReadOnly);\r\n\r\n$cert = $SourceStore.Certificates | Where-Object  -FilterScript {\r\n    $_.subject -like '*'\r\n};\r\n\r\n$DestStoreScope = 'LocalMachine';\r\n$DestStoreName = 'My';\r\n\r\n$DestStore = New-Object  -TypeName System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store  -ArgumentList $DestStoreName, $DestStoreScope;\r\n$DestStore.Open([System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.OpenFlags]::ReadWrite);\r\n$DestStore.Add($cert);\r\n\r\n$SourceStore.Close();\r\n$DestStore.Close();\r\n\r\nwinrm create winrm/config/listener?Address=*+Transport=HTTPS  `@`{Hostname=`\"($certId)`\"`;CertificateThumbprint=`\"($cert.Thumbprint)`\"`};\r\n\r\nRestart-Service winrm;\r\n</powershell>\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Steps to Reproduce Issue\r\n\r\nRunning salt-cloud:\r\n\r\n```\r\n...\r\n[DEBUG   ] Sending event: tag = salt/cloud/minion1/requesting; data = {'event': 'requesting instance', '_stamp': '2016-12-07T09:31:00.037859', 'location': 'eu-west-1', 'kwargs': {'UserData': '', 'SecurityGroup.0': 'am_offices_sg', 'ImageId': 'ami-a8592cdb', 'KeyName': 'acorcoles-saltstack-master-default', 'MaxCount': 1, 'Action': 'RunInstances', 'MinCount': 1, 'InstanceType': 't2.medium'}}\r\n[DEBUG   ] Using AWS endpoint: ec2.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com\r\n[DEBUG   ] AWS Request: https://ec2.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/?Action=RunInstances&ImageId=ami-a8592cdb&InstanceType=t2.medium&KeyName=acorcoles-saltstack-master-default&MaxCount=1&MinCount=1&SecurityGroup.0=am_offices_sg&UserData=PHBvd2Vyc2hlbGw%%3D%3D&Version=2014-10-01\r\n...\r\n```\r\n\r\nIf I run `base64 -d` on the userdata, I get:\r\n\r\n```\r\n<powershell> New-NetFirewallRule -Name \"SMB445\" -DisplayName \"SMB445\" -Protocol TCP -LocalPort 445 New-NetFirewallRule -Name \"WINRM5986\" -DisplayName \"WINRM5986\" -Protocol TCP -LocalPort 5986\r\nwinrm quickconfig -q winrm set winrm/config/winrs '@{MaxMemoryPerShellMB=\"300\"}' winrm set winrm/config '@{MaxTimeoutms=\"1800000\"}' winrm set winrm/config/service/auth '@{Basic=\"true\"}'\r\n$SourceStoreScope = 'LocalMachine' $SourceStorename = 'Remote Desktop'\r\n$SourceStore = New-Object  -TypeName System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store  -ArgumentList $SourceStorename, $SourceStoreScope $SourceStore.Open([System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.OpenFlags]::ReadOnly)\r\n$cert = $SourceStore.Certificates | Where-Object  -FilterScript { $_.subject -like '*' }\r\n$DestStoreScope = 'LocalMachine' $DestStoreName = 'My'\r\n$DestStore = New-Object  -TypeName System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Store  -ArgumentList $DestStoreName, $DestStoreScope $DestStore.Open([System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.OpenFlags]::ReadWrite) $DestStore.Add($cert)\r\n$SourceStore.Close() $DestStore.Close()\r\nwinrm create winrm/config/listener?Address=*+Transport=HTTPS  `@`{Hostname=`\"($certId)`\"`;CertificateThumbprint=`\"($cert.Thumbprint)`\"`}\r\nRestart-Service winrm </powershell>\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Versions Report\r\n\r\n```\r\nSalt Version:\r\n           Salt: 2016.11.0\r\n \r\nDependency Versions:\r\n           cffi: Not Installed\r\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\r\n       dateutil: Not Installed\r\n          gitdb: Not Installed\r\n      gitpython: Not Installed\r\n          ioflo: Not Installed\r\n         Jinja2: 2.7.2\r\n        libgit2: Not Installed\r\n        libnacl: Not Installed\r\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\r\n           Mako: Not Installed\r\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\r\n msgpack-python: 0.4.8\r\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\r\n      pycparser: Not Installed\r\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\r\n         pygit2: Not Installed\r\n         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2015, 02:00:19)\r\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\r\n         PyYAML: 3.10\r\n          PyZMQ: 15.3.0\r\n           RAET: Not Installed\r\n          smmap: Not Installed\r\n        timelib: Not Installed\r\n        Tornado: 4.2.1\r\n            ZMQ: 4.1.4\r\n \r\nSystem Versions:\r\n           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core\r\n        machine: x86_64\r\n        release: 3.10.0-327.10.1.el7.x86_64\r\n         system: Linux\r\n        version: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core\r\n```\r\n",

body:
{
    "id": 168679434,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/35097",
    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\n\nRecently I have discovered that some of my minions are becoming unresponsive when trying to do anything:\n\n```\ncn42:\n    Minion did not return. [No response]\ncn11:\n    Minion did not return. [No response]\ncn58:\n    Minion did not return. [No response]\ncn59:\n    Minion did not return. [No response]\n```\n\nI discovered they log this error then log nothing further until the salt-minion daemon is restarted:\n\n```\n2016-07-30 15:23:24,881 [salt.utils.process][ERROR   ][73716] An un-handled exception from the multiprocessing process 'SignalHandlingMultiprocessingProcess-1:151' was caught:\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/process.py\", line 613, in _run\n    return self._original_run()\n  File \"/usr/lib64/python2.7/multiprocessing/process.py\", line 114, in run\n    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/schedule.py\", line 652, in handle_func\n    with salt.utils.fopen(fn_, 'rb') as fp_:\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/__init__.py\", line 1209, in fopen\n    fhandle = open(*args, **kwargs)\nIOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/var/cache/salt/minion/proc/20160730152324736016'\n2016-07-30 15:23:25,060 [salt.minion      ][ERROR   ][73716] Exception [Errno 32] Broken pipe occurred in scheduled job\n```\n\nHere's another example from another minion:\n\n```\n2016-07-31 22:01:26,626 [salt.utils.process][ERROR   ][73692] An un-handled exception from the multiprocessing process 'SignalHandlingMultiprocessingProcess-1:182' was caught:\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/process.py\", line 613, in _run\n    return self._original_run()\n  File \"/usr/lib64/python2.7/multiprocessing/process.py\", line 114, in run\n    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/schedule.py\", line 652, in handle_func\n    with salt.utils.fopen(fn_, 'rb') as fp_:\n  File \"/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/__init__.py\", line 1209, in fopen\n    fhandle = open(*args, **kwargs)\nIOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/var/cache/salt/minion/proc/20160731220126606879'\n2016-07-31 22:01:26,650 [salt.minion      ][ERROR   ][73692] Exception [Errno 32] Broken pipe occurred in scheduled job\n```\n### Setup\n\nI have dozens of minions.  This issue seems to effect them randomly.  I cannot attribute any change to any state, schedule, version, or anything else.  They just started randomly failing.\n### Versions Report\n\nI have not been able to attribute this to a specific version.  All my minions run 2016.3.1 as does my master.\n\nMaster:\n\n```\nSalt Version:\n           Salt: 2016.3.1\n\nDependency Versions:\n           cffi: Not Installed\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\n       dateutil: 1.5\n          gitdb: Not Installed\n      gitpython: Not Installed\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n         Jinja2: 2.7.2\n        libgit2: Not Installed\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\n           Mako: Not Installed\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n msgpack-python: 0.4.6\n   mysql-python: Not Installed\n      pycparser: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n         pygit2: Not Installed\n         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2015, 02:00:19)\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\n         PyYAML: 3.11\n          PyZMQ: 14.7.0\n           RAET: Not Installed\n          smmap: Not Installed\n        timelib: Not Installed\n        Tornado: 4.2.1\n            ZMQ: 4.0.5\n\nSystem Versions:\n           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core\n        machine: x86_64\n        release: 3.10.0-327.4.5.el7.x86_64\n         system: Linux\n        version: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core\n```\n\nMinion:\n\n```\nSalt Version:\n           Salt: 2016.3.1\n\nDependency Versions:\n           cffi: Not Installed\n       cherrypy: Not Installed\n       dateutil: 1.5\n          gitdb: Not Installed\n      gitpython: Not Installed\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n         Jinja2: 2.7.2\n        libgit2: Not Installed\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\n           Mako: Not Installed\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

Recently I have discovered that some of my minions are becoming unresponsive when trying to do anything:

```
cn42:
    Minion did not return. [No response]
cn11:
    Minion did not return. [No response]
cn58:
    Minion did not return. [No response]
cn59:
    Minion did not return. [No response]
```

I discovered they log this error then log nothing further until the salt-minion daemon is restarted:

```
2016-07-30 15:23:24,881 [salt.utils.process][ERROR   ][73716] An un-handled exception from the multiprocessing process 'SignalHandlingMultiprocessingProcess-1:151' was caught:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/process.py", line 613, in _run
    return self._original_run()
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/multiprocessing/process.py", line 114, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/schedule.py", line 652, in handle_func
    with salt.utils.fopen(fn_, 'rb') as fp_:
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/__init__.py", line 1209, in fopen
    fhandle = open(*args, **kwargs)
IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/var/cache/salt/minion/proc/20160730152324736016'
2016-07-30 15:23:25,060 [salt.minion      ][ERROR   ][73716] Exception [Errno 32] Broken pipe occurred in scheduled job
```

Here's another example from another minion:

```
2016-07-31 22:01:26,626 [salt.utils.process][ERROR   ][73692] An un-handled exception from the multiprocessing process 'SignalHandlingMultiprocessingProcess-1:182' was caught:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/process.py", line 613, in _run
    return self._original_run()
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/multiprocessing/process.py", line 114, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/schedule.py", line 652, in handle_func
    with salt.utils.fopen(fn_, 'rb') as fp_:
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/__init__.py", line 1209, in fopen
    fhandle = open(*args, **kwargs)
IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/var/cache/salt/minion/proc/20160731220126606879'
2016-07-31 22:01:26,650 [salt.minion      ][ERROR   ][73692] Exception [Errno 32] Broken pipe occurred in scheduled job
```
### Setup

I have dozens of minions.  This issue seems to effect them randomly.  I cannot attribute any change to any state, schedule, version, or anything else.  They just started randomly failing.
### Versions Report

I have not been able to attribute this to a specific version.  All my minions run 2016.3.1 as does my master.

Master:

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.3.1

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: 1.5
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.7.2
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2015, 02:00:19)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 14.7.0
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.5

System Versions:
           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.10.0-327.4.5.el7.x86_64
         system: Linux
        version: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core
```

Minion:

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.3.1

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: 1.5
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
          ioflo: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.7.2
        libgit2: Not Installed
        libnacl: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.7
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2015, 02:00:19)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 14.7.0
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1
            ZMQ: 4.0.5

System Versions:
           dist: centos 7.2.1511 Core
        machine: x86_64
        release: 3.10.0-327.13.1.el7.x86_64
         system: Linux
        version: CentOS Linux 7.2.1511 Core
```

    "body": "### Description of Issue/Question\n\nWhen running webutil.user_exists state, salt minion issues warning:\n\n```\n2016-06-23 15:36:15,644 [py.warnings                                                 ][WARNING ][4810] /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/htpasswd.py:69:     DeprecationWarning: 'htpasswd.useradd_all' has been deprecated in favor of 'htpasswd.useradd'. It's functionality will be removed in Salt Nitrogen. Please migrate     to using 'useradd' instead of 'useradd_all'.\n```\n\nProbably it's initiated here:\nhttps://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/v2016.3.1/salt/states/htpasswd.py#L71\n\nDeprecation warning is here:\nhttps://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/v2016.3.1/salt/modules/htpasswd.py#L68\n### Versions Report\n\nSalt Version:\n           Salt: 2016.3.1\n\nDependency Versions:\n           cffi: Not Installed\n       cherrypy: 3.2.2\n       dateutil: 1.5\n          gitdb: 0.5.4\n      gitpython: 0.3.2 RC1\n          ioflo: Not Installed\n         Jinja2: 2.6\n        libgit2: Not Installed\n        libnacl: Not Installed\n       M2Crypto: Not Installed\n           Mako: 0.7.0\n   msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n msgpack-python: 0.3.0\n   mysql-python: 1.2.3\n      pycparser: Not Installed\n       pycrypto: 2.6.1\n         pygit2: Not Installed\n         Python: 2.7.3 (default, Jun 21 2016, 18:38:19)\n   python-gnupg: Not Installed\n         PyYAML: 3.10\n          PyZMQ: 13.1.0\n           RAET: Not Installed\n          smmap: 0.8.2\n        timelib: Not Installed\n        Tornado: 4.2.1\n            ZMQ: 3.2.3\n\nSystem Versions:\n           dist: debian 7.11 \n        machine: x86_64\n        release: 3.2.0-4-amd64\n         system: Linux\n        version: debian 7.11 \n",

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

When running webutil.user_exists state, salt minion issues warning:

```
2016-06-23 15:36:15,644 [py.warnings                                                 ][WARNING ][4810] /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/salt/modules/htpasswd.py:69:     DeprecationWarning: 'htpasswd.useradd_all' has been deprecated in favor of 'htpasswd.useradd'. It's functionality will be removed in Salt Nitrogen. Please migrate     to using 'useradd' instead of 'useradd_all'.
```

Probably it's initiated here:
https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/v2016.3.1/salt/states/htpasswd.py#L71

Deprecation warning is here:
https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/v2016.3.1/salt/modules/htpasswd.py#L68

    "body": "**Description**\r\n\r\nThe current examples for the zypperpkg `add_lock` and `remove_lock` methods include a non-working example.\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/0f585604b775e3f284406b2be5841bcd4d44e6d6/salt/modules/zypperpkg.py#L1894\r\n\r\nhttps://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/0f585604b775e3f284406b2be5841bcd4d44e6d6/salt/modules/zypperpkg.py#L1927\r\n\r\n**Steps to Reproduce the behavior**\r\n\r\n```\r\nsalt-call pkg.add_lock pkgs='[\"foo\", \"bar\"]'\r\nsalt-call pkg.remove_lock pkgs='[\"foo\", \"bar\"]'\r\n```\r\n\r\n<details><summary>Errors from `add_lock` (similar for `remove_lock`)</summary>\r\n\r\n```text\r\na6ec4f481e57:/ # salt-call pkg.add_lock pkgs='[\"foo\", \"bar\"]'\r\n\r\nPassed invalid arguments: add_lock() missing 1 required positional argument: 'packages'.\r\n\r\nUsage:\r\n\r\n    Add a package lock. {
    "body": [
        "**Description**

The current examples for the zypperpkg `add_lock` and `remove_lock` methods include a non-working example.

https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/0f585604b775e3f284406b2be5841bcd4d44e6d6/salt/modules/zypperpkg.py#L1894

https://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/0f585604b775e3f284406b2be5841bcd4d44e6d6/salt/modules/zypperpkg.py#L1927

**Steps to Reproduce the behavior**

```
salt-call pkg.add_lock pkgs='["foo", "bar"]'
salt-call pkg.remove_lock pkgs='["foo", "bar"]'
```

<details><summary>Errors from `add_lock` (similar for `remove_lock`)</summary>

```text
a6ec4f481e57:/ # salt-call pkg.add_lock pkgs='["foo", "bar"]'

Passed invalid arguments: add_lock() missing 1 required positional argument: 'packages'.

Usage:

    Add a package lock. Specify packages to lock by exact name.

    CLI Example:

    .. code-block:: bash

        salt '*' pkg.add_lock <package name>
        salt '*' pkg.add_lock <package1>,<package2>,<package3>
        salt '*' pkg.add_lock pkgs='["foo", "bar"]'
    
a6ec4f481e57:/ # salt-call pkg.add_lock packages='["foo", "bar"]'
[ERROR   ] An un-handled exception was caught by salt's global exception handler:
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'split'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/salt-call", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(salt_call())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/scripts.py", line 472, in salt_call
    client.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/cli/call.py", line 58, in run
    caller.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/cli/caller.py", line 121, in run
    ret = self.call()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/cli/caller.py", line 229, in call
    self.opts, data, func, args, kwargs
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/executors/direct_call.py", line 12, in execute
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/modules/zypperpkg.py", line 1932, in add_lock
    packages = list(__salt__["pkg_resource.parse_targets"](packages)[0].keys())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/modules/pkg_resource.py", line 174, in parse_targets
    packed = dict([(_normalize_name(x), version) for x in name.split(",")])
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'split'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/salt-call", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(salt_call())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/scripts.py", line 472, in salt_call
    client.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/cli/call.py", line 58, in run
    caller.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/cli/caller.py", line 121, in run
    ret = self.call()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/cli/caller.py", line 229, in call
    self.opts, data, func, args, kwargs
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/executors/direct_call.py", line 12, in execute
    return func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/modules/zypperpkg.py", line 1932, in add_lock
    packages = list(__salt__["pkg_resource.parse_targets"](packages)[0].keys())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/salt/modules/pkg_resource.py", line 174, in parse_targets
    packed = dict([(_normalize_name(x), version) for x in name.split(",")])
AttributeError: 'list' object has no attribute 'split'
```

</details>

**Expected behavior**

All documented examples should work.

**Versions Report**


<details><summary>salt --versions-report</summary>
(Provided by running salt --versions-report. Please also mention any differences in master/minion versions.) 

Installed with `bootstrap-salt.sh -X -x python3 git master`.

```
Salt Version:
           Salt: 3000-n/a-a8d3c06
 
Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: Not Installed
      docker-py: Not Installed
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed
         Jinja2: 2.11.2
        libgit2: Not Installed
       M2Crypto: Not Installed
           Mako: Not Installed
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.6.2
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: Not Installed
   pycryptodome: 3.9.7
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 3.6.10 (default, Jan 16 2020, 09:12:04) [GCC]
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 5.3.1
          PyZMQ: 19.0.0
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.5.3
            ZMQ: 4.3.2
 
System Versions:
           dist:   
         locale: UTF-8
        machine: x86_64
        release: 5.3.0-46-generic
         system: Linux
        version: Not Installed
```

</details>

**Additional context**

Note that this is also a problem in the published SuSE packages.  In their latest packages, these two methods are flagged as deprecated for their provided `hold`/`unhold` methods (#50773), which are not currently part of released Open.
"

    "id": 559236147,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/56053",
    "body": "### master_roots\r\nI have started to refactor our master and I started with updating the master from 2019.2.0 to 2019.2.3(py2).  Then have uncommented this line in the config and I get this warning message.\r\n```\r\n[WARNING ] Config option 'master_roots' with value /srv/salt-master has an invalid type of unicode, a dict is required for this option\r\n```\r\n\r\n### Documentation\r\nI have found the documentation to be inaccurate and unclear about this option\r\nhttps://docs.saltstack.com/en/latest/ref/configuration/master.html#master-roots\r\n\r\nWe are planning to only use gitfs and was wounding if it is not an idea to have this opting supported by gitfs aswell.",

{
    "body": [
        "### Description of Issue/Question

The following state is waiting forever for a confirmation:

```
Disable_modules:
  apache_module.disabled:
    - name: autoindex 
```

Because when I ran the command manualy:

```
~$ sudo /usr/sbin/a2dismod autoindex
WARNING: The following essential module will be disabled.
This might result in unexpected behavior and should NOT be done
unless you know exactly what you are doing!
 autoindex

To continue type in the phrase 'Yes, do as I say!' or retry by passing '-f':
```

The apache_module state would require a 'force' parameter to prevent this. Or run the relevant command with the -f by default.
### Versions Report

```
~$ salt-call --versions-report
Salt Version:
           Salt: 2016.3.1

Dependency Versions:
           cffi: Not Installed
       cherrypy: Not Installed
       dateutil: 2.4.2
          gitdb: Not Installed
      gitpython: Not Installed

           Mako: 1.0.3
   msgpack-pure: Not Installed
 msgpack-python: 0.4.6
   mysql-python: Not Installed
      pycparser: Not Installed
       pycrypto: 2.6.1
         pygit2: Not Installed
         Python: 2.7.11+ (default, Apr 17 2016, 14:00:29)
   python-gnupg: Not Installed
         PyYAML: 3.11
          PyZMQ: 15.2.0
           RAET: Not Installed
          smmap: Not Installed
        timelib: Not Installed
        Tornado: 4.2.1

System Versions:
           dist: Ubuntu 16.04 xenial
        machine: x86_64
        release: 4.4.0-28-generic
         system: Linux
        version: Ubuntu 16.04 xenial
```
"

{
    "id": 107674082,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/27293",
    "body": "I am testing runit module and while trying to stop/restar a service I am getting something like this:\n\n```\n ERROR: Unable to run command ['sv', 'restart', '/service/buildbot'] with the context {'with_communicate': True, 'shell': False, 'env': {'PWD': '/', 'HOME': '/', 'PATH': '/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin', 'PYTHON_EGG_CACHE': '/tmp', 'LC_ALL': 'C', 'RC_PID': '21'}, 'stdout': -1, 'close_fds': True, 'stdin': None, 'stderr': -2, 'cwd': '/'}, reason: [Errno 2] No such file or directory\n```\n\nProblem is that PATH is only set to: \n\n```\n'PATH': '/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin'\n```\n\nand the sv program is in `/usr/local/sbin/sv`\n\nHow to extend the PATH globally per minion ?\n\n`salt * grains.items` returns the full path:\n\n```\n/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/local/sbin\n```\n",
