body:
{
    "id": 107436388,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/27266",
    "body": "So I know I can watch a directory for changes, but I would like to trigger a service restart at the end of a salt run with listen. Unfortunately, that does not appear to be supported.\n\nSalt returns the following\n\n```\n----------\n          ID: listen_/etc/sensu/conf.d*\n    Function: Listen_Error.Listen_Error\n        Name: listen_file\n      Result: False\n     Comment: Referenced state file: /etc/sensu/conf.d* does not exist\n     Started:\n    Duration:\n     Changes:\n```\n\nand the corresponding snippet from my SLS file\n\n```\nsensu-client:\n  service.running:\n   [...]\n    - listen:\n      - file: /etc/sensu/conf.d/*\n```\n\nFor the short term, I will revert back to watch, but I feel like this behavior should also exist for listen.\n\nRelated issue: https://github.com/saltstack/salt/issues/663\n",

        "id": 2318521,

body:
{
    "id": 101754778,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/26448",
    "body": "Given the following two orchestration states to initiate 'highstate':

```
##using salt.function
install_primary_minions:
  salt.function:
    - name: state.highstate
    - tgt: 'dbarmor-acc01*'
```

```
##using salt.state
install_primary_minions:
  salt.state:
    - highstate: True
    - tgt: 'dbarmor-acc01*'
```

The first example above works just like the command-line.  **The second throws the following error:**

```
[ERROR   ] Run failed on minions: dbarmor-acc01
Failures:
    dbarmor-acc01:
        Data failed to compile:
    ----------
        No matching sls found for 'dbarmor' in env 'acc'
```

It doesn't appear that 'salt.state:  - highstate: True' is evaluating top.sls and/or environments properly.  The states in /srv/salt/base/\* are 'templates' that reference pillar data.  top.sls has a single 'base' environment section where minions are assigned roles using minion name.  States are assigned to minions based on the roles.  Each environment has minions that use the same roles.
# /srv/salt/base/top.sls:

```
base:
#ROLE Assignments:
  'E@go-agent\..+':
    - go.role_go_agent
  'E@dbarmor-(dev|acc).+':
    - dbarmor.role_processor
  'E@dbarmor-(dev|acc)0[1-2]\..+':
    - dbarmor.role_web
  'E@dbarmor-(dev|acc)01\..+':
    - dbarmor.role_primary_rabbit
  'E@dbarmor-(dev|acc)(?!01).+':
    - dbarmor.role_secondary_rabbit
#STATE Assignments based on ROLE:
  'G@role:dbarmor_processor':
    - dbarmor.dbarmor-processor
  'G@role:dbarmor_web':
    - dbarmor.dbarmor-web
  'G@role:dbarmor_primary_rabbit':
    - dbarmor.dbarmor-rabbitmq
  'G@role:dbarmor_secondary_rabbit':
    - dbarmor.dbarmor-rabbitmq
```

Pillar top.sls is where minions are assigned environment environment-specific values that are used in the template state files.  
# /srv/pillar/base/top.sls:

```
dev:
  'rjv-test02*':
    - dbarmor
acc:
  'dbarmor-acc*':
    - dbarmor
```
# FILE LAYOUT

```
/srv
├── pillar
│   ├── acc
│   │   ├── dbarmor
│   │   │   ├── globals.yml
│   │   │   ├── init.sls
│   │   │   ├── processor_jar.sls
│   │   │   ├── rabbitmq_pillar.sls
│   │   │   └── war_file.sls
│   │   └── updater
│   ├── base
│   │   ├── dbrisklevelutils
│   │   │   └── init.sls
│   │   ├── ratingtool
│   │   │   ├── props.sls
│   │   │   └── war_file.sls
│   │   ├── salt-formula
│   │   └── top.sls
│   └── dev
│       ├── dbarmor
│       │   ├── init.sls
│       │   ├── processor_jar.sls
│       │   ├── rabbitmq_pillar.sls
│       │   └── war_file.sls
│       └── dbrisklevelutils
│           └── init.sls
└── salt
    └── base
        ├── dbarmor
        │   ├── catalina.properties
        │   ├── dbarmor-processor.conf
        │   ├── dbarmor-processor.properties
        │   ├── dbarmorProcessor.sh
        │   ├── dbarmor-processor.sls
        │   ├── dbarmor-rabbitmq.sls
        │   ├── dbarmor-web.properties
        │   ├── dbarmor-web.sls
        │   ├── erlang.cookie
        │   ├── role_primary_rabbit.sls
        │   ├── role_processor.sls
        │   ├── role_secondary_rabbit.sls
        │   └── role_web.sls
        ├── openssh
        │   ├── init.sls
        │   ├── openssh-server.sls
        │   ├── ssh_config
        │   └── sshd_config
        ├── oracle-java
        │   ├── oracle-java7.sls
```

```
##using salt.function
install_primary_minions:
  salt.function:
    - name: state.highstate
    - tgt: 'dbarmor-acc01*'
```

```
##using salt.state
install_primary_minions:
  salt.state:
    - highstate: True
    - tgt: 'dbarmor-acc01*'
```

The first example above works just like the command-line.  **The second throws the following error:**

```
[ERROR   ] Run failed on minions: dbarmor-acc01
Failures:
    dbarmor-acc01:
        Data failed to compile:
    ----------
        No matching sls found for 'dbarmor' in env 'acc'
```

It doesn't appear that 'salt.state:  - highstate: True' is evaluating top.sls and/or environments properly.  The states in /srv/salt/base/\* are 'templates' that reference pillar data.  top.sls has a single 'base' environment section where minions are assigned roles using minion name.  States are assigned to minions based on the roles.  Each environment has minions that use the same roles.

body:
{
    "id": 99507527,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/26073",
    "body": "For some reason when the timeout is set too high on salt commands, it never timesout on unconnected or not responding minions.  When the timeout is low it properly drops, but it seems above ~13 seconds or so in our setup causes it to never fail.  I've let jobs run overnight, and they continually send the jid check event, while no further minions are returning:\n\n```\n[DEBUG   ] MasterEvent PUB socket URI: ipc:///var/run/salt/master/master_event_pub.ipc\n[DEBUG   ] MasterEvent PULL socket URI: ipc:///var/run/salt/master/master_event_pull.ipc\n[DEBUG   ] Sending event - data = {'_stamp': '2015-08-06T19:24:56.930262'}\n[DEBUG   ] Checking whether jid 20150806122354756801 is still running\n```\n\nIs it possible this event is actually resetting the timeout?\n\n```\n                  Salt: 2015.5.3\n                Python: 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:56)\n                Jinja2: 2.7.2\n              M2Crypto: 0.21.1\n        msgpack-python: 0.3.0\n          msgpack-pure: Not Installed\n              pycrypto: 2.6.1\n               libnacl: Not Installed\n                PyYAML: 3.10\n                 ioflo: Not Installed\n                 PyZMQ: 14.0.1\n                  RAET: Not Installed\n                   ZMQ: 4.0.4\n                  Mako: 0.9.1\n               Tornado: Not Installed\n Debian source package: 2015.5.3+ds-1trusty1\n```\n\nTalking with others in #salt, it doesn't sound like anyone else has hit this.  All minions are also 2015.5.3.  Has anyone else seen this?  The relevant bits of our simple master config:\n\n```\ncon_cache: True\nfile_buffer_size: 10486750\nstate_output: mixed\ntimeout: 15\norder_masters: True\npillar_opts: False\nstate_aggregate: True\nstate_verbose: False\ncachedir: /opt/cache/salt/master\nworker_threads: 20\n```\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "For some reason when the timeout is set too high on salt commands, it never timesout on unconnected or not responding minions.  When the timeout is low it properly drops, but it seems above ~13 seconds or so in our setup causes it to never fail.  I've let jobs run overnight, and they continually send the jid check event, while no further minions are returning:

```
[DEBUG   ] MasterEvent PUB socket URI: ipc:///var/run/salt/master/master_event_pub.ipc
[DEBUG   ] MasterEvent PULL socket URI: ipc:///var/run/salt/master/master_event_pull.ipc
[DEBUG   ] Sending event - data = {'_stamp': '2015-08-06T19:24:56.930262'}
[DEBUG   ] Checking whether jid 20150806122354756801 is still running
```

Is it possible this event is actually resetting the timeout?

```
                  Salt: 2015.5.3
                Python: 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:56)
                Jinja2: 2.7.2
              M2Crypto: 0.21.1
        msgpack-python: 0.3.0
          msgpack-pure: Not Installed
              pycrypto: 2.6.1
               libnacl: Not Installed
                PyYAML: 3.10
                 ioflo: Not Installed
                 PyZMQ: 14.0.1
                  RAET: Not Installed
                   ZMQ: 4.0.4
                  Mako: 0.9.1
               Tornado: Not Installed
 Debian source package: 2015.5.3+ds-1trusty1
```

Talking with others in #salt, it doesn't sound like anyone else has hit this.  All minions are also 2015.5.3.  Has anyone else seen this?  The relevant bits of our simple master config:

```
con_cache: True
file_buffer_size: 10486750
state_output: mixed
timeout: 15
order_masters: True
pillar_opts: False
state_aggregate: True
state_verbose: False
cachedir: /opt/cache/salt/master
worker_threads: 20
```
"
    ],
    "title": [
        "Timeout gets reset by event on the bus on 2015.5.3"
    ],
    "labels": [
        {
            "name": "Bug",

}

body:
{
    "id": 76253464,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/23700",
    "body": "Given the following:\n\n```\ndemo cron:\n  cron.present:\n    - name: /bin/echo 'Spooky!'\n    - user: mp\n    - minute: 0\n    - hour: 0\n    - comment: 'Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered weak and weary'\n```\n\nThis error is produced:\n\n```\nlocal:\n----------\n          ID: demo cron\n    Function: cron.present\n        Name: /bin/echo\n      Result: False\n     Comment: Cron /bin/echo for user mp failed to commit with error \n              /tmp/tmpR9WFWz: Permission denied\n     Started: 00:17:05.341055\n    Duration: 27.531 ms\n     Changes:   \n\nSummary\n------------\nSucceeded: 0\nFailed:    1\n------------\n```\n\nThis seems to be due to the tmp file being created without perms for the intended user to then read it and install in his/her crontab. A diff like the following fixes it, but probably isn't the right fix:\n\n```\ndiff --git a/salt/modules/cron.py b/salt/modules/cron.py\nindex 555843d..1ac3c84 100644\n--- a/salt/modules/cron.py\n+++ b/salt/modules/cron.py\n@@ -186,7 +186,7 @@ def _write_cron_lines(user, lines):\n     path = salt.utils.mkstemp()\n     with salt.utils.fopen(path, 'w+') as fp_:\n         fp_.writelines(lines)\n-    if __grains__.get('os_family') in ('Solaris', 'AIX') and user != \"root\":\n+    if __grains__.get('os_family') in ('Solaris', 'AIX', 'Arch') and user != \"root\":\n         __salt__['cmd.run']('chown {0} {1}'.format(user, path),\n                             python_shell=False)\n     ret = __salt__['cmd.run_all'](_get_cron_cmdstr(path),\n```\n",

extracted_body:
{
    "body": [
        "Given the following:

```
demo cron:
  cron.present:
    - name: /bin/echo 'Spooky!'
    - user: mp
    - minute: 0
    - hour: 0
    - comment: 'Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered weak and weary'
```

This error is produced:

```
local:
----------
          ID: demo cron
    Function: cron.present
        Name: /bin/echo
      Result: False
     Comment: Cron /bin/echo for user mp failed to commit with error 
              /tmp/tmpR9WFWz: Permission denied
     Started: 00:17:05.341055
    Duration: 27.531 ms
     Changes:   

Summary
------------
Succeeded: 0
Failed:    1
------------
```

This seems to be due to the tmp file being created without perms for the intended user to then read it and install in his/her crontab. A diff like the following fixes it, but probably isn't the right fix:

```
diff --git a/salt/modules/cron.py b/salt/modules/cron.py
index 555843d..1ac3c84 100644
--- a/salt/modules/cron.py
+++ b/salt/modules/cron.py
@@ -186,7 +186,7 @@ def _write_cron_lines(user, lines):
     path = salt.utils.mkstemp()
     with salt.utils.fopen(path, 'w+') as fp_:
         fp_.writelines(lines)
-    if __grains__.get('os_family') in ('Solaris', 'AIX') and user != "root":
+    if __grains__.get('os_family') in ('Solaris', 'AIX', 'Arch') and user != "root":
         __salt__['cmd.run']('chown {0} {1}'.format(user, path),
                             python_shell=False)
     ret = __salt__['cmd.run_all'](_get_cron_cmdstr(path),
```

    "id": 48770423,
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/saltstack/salt/issues/18088",
    "body": "I recently updated to the latest version in `2014.7` branch and now I get the following backtrace when trying to apply any state which uses the `pyobjects` renderer:\n\n```\n[CRITICAL] Rendering SLS docker.containers failed, render error: 'function' object has no attribute 'split'\nhost:\n    - Rendering SLS docker.containers failed, render error: 'function' object has no attribute 'split'\n    - Traceback (most recent call last):\n    -   File \"/home/kostko/development/virtualenvs/salt/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/state.py\", line 2408, in render_state\n    -     sls, rendered_sls=mods\n    -   File \"/home/kostko/development/virtualenvs/salt/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/template.py\", line 84, in compile_template\n    -     ret = render(input_data, saltenv, sls, **render_kwargs)\n    -   File \"/home/kostko/development/virtualenvs/salt/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/renderers/pyobjects.py\", line 359, in render\n    -     'salt': SaltObject(__salt__),\n    -   File \"/home/kostko/development/virtualenvs/salt/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/salt/utils/pyobjects.py\", line 279, in __init__\n    -     mod, func = full_func.split('.')\n    - AttributeError: 'function' object has no attribute 'split'\n```\n",

    "body": "Looks like the latest 2014.1.2 assumes the presence of `zmq` for some freezer related code. This prevents it installing here, since I don't have `zmq` (`HAS_ZMQ is False`).\n\nhttps://github.com/saltstack/salt/blob/v2014.1.2/setup.py#L516\n\nIf I swap lines 516 and 517 then the install works as expected.\n",
